qas.question: What disciplines were women trained in during the first century?
Who was the most well known female scholar in Islamic schools?
When was formal education for Islamic women halted?
During which Caliphate did Islamic women begin attending formal school?
What disciplines were women trained in during the second century?
Who was the least well known female scholar in Islamic schools?
When was formal education for Islamic women encouraged?
During which Caliphate did Islamic women stop going to formal school?

context: From around 750, during the <a4_0>Abbasid<a4_0/> Caliphate, women “became renowned for their brains as well as their beauty”. In particular, many well known women of the time were trained from childhood in <a0_0><b5_0>music, dancing and poetry<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Mahbuba was one of these. Another feminine figure to be remembered for her achievements was Tawaddud, "a slave girl who was said to have been bought at great cost by Hārūn al-Rashīd because she had passed her examinations by the most eminent scholars in astronomy, medicine, law, philosophy, music, history, Arabic grammar, literature, theology and chess". Moreover, among the most prominent feminine figures was <a1_0><b6_0>Shuhda<b6_0/><a1_0/> who was known as "the Scholar" or "the Pride of Women" during the 12th century in <a2_0><b7_0>Baghdad<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Despite the recognition of women's aptitudes during the <b9_0>Abbasid<b9_0/> dynasty, all these came to an end in Iraq with the sack of Baghdad in <a3_0><b8_0>1258<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
